updates.update_content:
Hi everyone,
It has been a while. We hope you are all enjoying your copies of Heroes of the Realm. If you are, please do consider posting a review on Amazon, GoodReads, or anywhere else you prefer. Also, if you know anyone who missed out on the campaign and is interested in getting a copy of the book, it is available at most internet booksellers in print and ebook.
In the meantime, eSpec Books is running a campaign that might be of interest to you. It is for the re-release of the novel , by Danielle Ackley-McPhail and Day Al-Mohamed. The book was originally published in 2012 but the previous publisher ceased to be, and so did the book. This is a steampunk retelling of Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves.

Thanks for being patient, folks, while we read through the submissions to select our winner. Let me tell you, it was a difficult choice.
You know what, though? You are all winners because we wanted to make sure you had a lot of quality reading for your reward. Not only did we accept *two* open submission stories, but I threw one in as well to make up for not unlocking as many submission slots as we had hoped.

Please help us track your add-on swag that you scooped up during the campaign. 

As we organize our rewards to be sure you all get them over the coming months, we want to be sure to track the add-ons in a tidy way, so I've created this little survey.

It's Time to Wrap Some Details Around those Rewards!
April 1st is already here, and we promise the email we sent you all today is not a setup for a prank. You should have received an email containing your backer survey, which will help us collect those details that make it possible to deliver the rewards you selected when you so graciously backed our campaign at the beginning of this year.

updates.update_userinfo: Happy Spring to All Our Heroes
updates.update_content:
We've come so far in the last 27 days, friends.
So many of you have come along side us and funded RealmScapes: Heroes of the Realm ahead of schedule. We've even made our first $500 stretch goal, which means well be able to send EVERY backer more short fiction from our core authors. Even better, we'll be able to comb the submission stories to add another fantastic tale to the book.
We're just $381 away from adding another story, as well as releasing more of those short fiction titles to our backers. I'd love to close this campaign out having added two stories (or more; I'm a dreamer like that)--and I know the authors who have submitted their work for those potential slots are hoping for that chance at publication as well.

campaign.story:
What is Strange Horizons? 
Strange Horizons is a weekly online magazine of and about speculative fiction—science fiction, fantasy, horror, slipstream, and all other flavors of imaginative fiction—and related non-fiction. Since September 2000, we have been publishing new issues every Monday, including fiction, poetry, reviews, essays, and interviews. In 2017, we published almost 1,000,000 words over 51 issues, all paid to our contributors, and all paid for by you, our supporters.
We're entirely funded by voluntary contributions. We pay all our contributors fair market rates for their work, but our (frankly enormous) volunteer editorial team does it out of love.
Why support Strange Horizons?
Because we believe that in the twenty-first century, speculative fiction must be an open, global tradition. For over fifteen years, we have showcased work that challenges us and delights us, by new and established writers from diverse backgrounds and with diverse concerns. 
Because we have a record of finding and supporting exciting new voices in SF: writers who got their start in Strange Horizons include N. K. Jemisin ("The You Train," from 2007), Justine Larbalestier ("The Cruel Brother," from 2001), Ken Liu ("The Algorithms for Love," from 2004), Nnedi Okorafor ("The Palm Tree Bandit," from 2000), John Scalzi ("Alien Animal Encounters," from 2001) and, in more recent years, G. V. Anderson ("Das Steingeschöpf", from 2016).
Because we're a multiple Hugo-shortlisted magazine (for six consecutive years!) and we've published stories that have been shortlisted for or won Hugo, Nebula, James Tiptree Jr., Theodore Sturgeon, and World Fantasy Awards.
What We Need
What we need to raise:
We need $13,000 to fund the basic running costs of the magazine for 1 year
At $14,500 we'll run a special issue packed with international SFF 
At $16,000 we'll run a special issue focused on web comics 
At $21,000 we'll be able to 🎉 pay our staff 🎉for the first time in our history
If we hit $23,000 we'll unlock the first stretch goal 
And at $25,000 we'll unlock the second secret goal!
What You Get
What do you get out of this?
If you donate $25 you get access to all of 2018's Strange Horizons ebooks 
If you donate $40 you get the above and digital wallpaper of our 2018 artwork for your computer/phone/device.
If you donate $50 you get the above and a mug, t-shirt or tote bag branded with the Strange Horizons logo
If you donate $75 you don't have to choose! You get a mug, t-shirt and tote, as well as all lower tier rewards.
If you donate $100 you get all lower tier rewards and a set of art postcards, featuring all of the art from this year.
If you donate $150 you get one of our special limited edition Strange Horizons lapel pins and all the $75 rewards.
More than that, for each funding milestone that we reach, we'll publish more bonus content for you to enjoy:
$3,000 – bonus fiction by Margaret Killjoy
$5,000 – bonus article by Darcie Little Badger
$7,000 – 2 bonus poems by Mary Soon Lee
$9,000 – bonus review by Erin Horáková 
$11,000 – bonus fiction by Natalia Theodoridou
$13,000 – SH is fully funded! E-books for all donors!
Other Ways You Can Help
Tweet about the fund drive! Tell everyone you know what you love about Strange Horizons and why we're worth supporting.
Ask people to read the magazine!

Hello to our wonderful backers from last year's fund drive. We hope you are enjoying the content you funded for 2019--we've enjoyed bringing it to you! 
The fund drive for 2020--our nineteenth year, leading up to our 20th anniversary--is now live, with new, colorful rewards and stretch goals. We're aiming to raise writers' pay to 10 cents per word, as well as fund a Mexican special and a climate change special. There are shiny new pins featuring our purple planet, as well as the adorable axolotl, a Very Serious snek, and trans Jupiter. Merc Rustad and Nin Harris will write new interactive Twitter threads for donations. We've got autographed books and edits from the SH staff, all options for you should you choose to renew your support.

The Kickstarter Has Ended, BUT …
You can still get the ebooks and Kickstarter editions of the paperbacks by preordering them at the Zombies Need Brains store:  https://squareup.com/market/zombies-need-brains-llc.  Plus, you can sign up for our newsletter at:  http://www.zombiesneedbrains.com/.  Follow us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/zombiesneedbrainsllc/) and on Twitter @ZNBLLC.
Submission Guidelines:
We funded!  Which means we've got some anthologies to fill.  If you've written a story that fits our themes, or one of them sparks an idea, send it in to our open call.  You may end up in one of our anthologies!  Official guidelines with manuscript formatting and email contact for questions and submissions here: https://jpskewedthrone.dreamwidth.org/496776.html.  You can also find them in Update #17.
Now go get writing!  We want to see your stories!
First 20 Backers:  The first 20 backers pledging $20 or more will receive a signed business card from Faith Hunter, a signed bookmark from V.M. Escalada for her novel HALLS OF LAW, a ZNB magnet, and one of an assortment of a signed bookmarks from either Jean Marie Ward or Kay Kenyon!
The Next 50 Backers: The next 50 backers pledging $20 or more will receive a "Jane Yellowrock" business card and bookmark from Faith Hunter!
First Day Backers: Anyone pledging $7 or more during the first 24 hours of the Kickstarter will receive the ebook "Beast" by Jaime Lee Moyer!
Pre $5K Incentive: All backers pledging $7 or more before the Kickstarter reaches $5,000 will receive a full current set of 16 Print-Them-Yourself bookmark files from Gini Koch's "Alien" series!
Pre $10K Incentive: Anyone pledging $7 or more before the Kickstarter hits $10,000 will receive the ebook "A Tapestry of Twelve Tales" by Stephen Leigh!
Pre $15K Incentive:  All backers pledging $7 or more before the Kickstarter hits $15,000 will receive the ebook "A Cup of Joe" by Anita Ensal (aka Gini Koch)!
Pre $20K Incentive:  All backers pledging $7 or more before the Kickstarter reaches $20,000 will receive the ebook "Random Musings from the Funny Girl" by Gini Koch!
High Backer Incentive: $250 or Over: Everyone pledging $250 or more will receive an out-of-print Kickstarter edition of CLOCKWORK UNIVERSE: STEAMPUNK VS ALIENS, the first Zombies Need Brains anthology!
Note: All Early Backer and High Backer incentives will be sent after the successful completion of the Kickstarter.
This project will fund THREE science fiction and fantasy anthologies, titled PORTALS, TEMPORALLY DEACTIVATED, and ALTERNATE PEACE, containing approximately 14 all-original (no reprint) short stories each from established SF&F authors in the field. The books will be edited by Patricia Bray & S.C. Butler (PORTALS), David B. Coe & Joshua Palmatier (TEMPORALLY DEACTIVATED), and Steven H Silver & Joshua Palmatier (ALTERNATE PEACE).
Unlike the first two Kickstarters run by Zombies Need Brains, we are NOT using the Kickstarter to help set up and solidify the small press. Backers of this project will essentially be generating the base funds needed to produce these three anthologies—including payment for the contributing authors, payment for the cover artist, production costs for producing the anthology, etc. Because of this, the reward levels for the anthologies have been set to more closely resemble the cost of the final product when it goes on sale to the general public. In essence, backers of the project are simply “preordering” the anthologies, although there will still be a special mass market Kickstarter edition produced for backers who help fund the project at the paperback level. This special edition will have a limited print run to cover the orders made by the backers and will not be printed again after the Kickstarter print run. After that, there will be a trade edition issued to the general public that will have an unlimited print run.
So get in on the Kickstarter now and get the special mass market Kickstarter edition! Help the small press Zombies Need Brains LLC expand! ZNB produces quality anthologies from leading authors. Check out our current offerings: 
Temporally Out of Order 
Alien Artifacts 
Were- 
Submerged 
All Hail Our Robot Conquerors! 
The Death of All Things
Guilds & Glaives
Second Round: A Return to the Ur-Bar
The Razor's Edge
at https://squareup.com/market/zombies-need-brains-llc. You can also find them online at Amazon.com and Barnes & Noble; they are available in trade paperback format as well as on almost all ebook platforms (Kindle, Nook, Kobo, Scribd, etc.).
We offer professional pay rates and feature stellar cover art. As we did in our previous anthologies, we plan to include the very best stories we can find, spanning the gamut from bestselling authors to new, previously unpublished voices, including an open submission window if the Kickstarter is successful, where anyone can submit their stories featuring the current themes for a chance to be part of the anthologies. And Zombies Need Brains is officially a "qualifying market" for the Science Fiction Writers of America (SFWA)! With your help, we hope that ZNB will then be able to expand into novels and other projects in the future. We can't do this without you! Consider backing our Kickstarter and then help spread the word. Just as Zombies Need Brains, we need your support to make this new small press a success. So what are the current projects? Here are the details:
PORTALS:
In the blink of an eye, the familiar disappears as you step into the unknown. What new creatures will you meet? What strange planets will you explore? Will you find happiness, or doom? Open the pages of PORTALS, the newest anthology from the small press Zombies Need Brains, and you just might find out.
From wardrobes to monoliths, wormholes to fairy rings, there is a rich tradition of stories in both science fiction and fantasy that explore what happens when--by accident or design--characters are transported from one world to another. Join fourteen of today’s leading science fiction and fantasy authors as they offer fresh takes on this classic theme. Whether a routine trip or unexpected journey, each tale will explore new worlds of adventure, mystery, humor, and horror, with stories for every taste and fancy.
Edited by S.C. Butler and Patricia Bray, PORTALS will contain approximately fourteen stories with an average length of up to 6,000 words each. It will include short stories by: 
Jacey Bedford
F. Brett Cox
James Enge 
Esther Friesner 
Nancy Holzner 
Gini Koch 
Violette Malan 
Jaime Lee Moyer
Ian Tregillis
All other slots aside from the named authors will be filled by the open call for submissions following the successful completion of the Kickstarter.
TEMPORALLY DEACTIVATED:
In our spam boxes today, we both received notices that our bank accounts required resolution, and the content of the spam contained the following sentence: "We have noticed that you need to resolve important security issues on your account to prevent temporal deactivation." Of course, our immediate thought was of a new anthology called TEMPORALLY DEACTIVATED!
For this follow-up to 2015’s TEMPORALLY OUT OF ORDER, we are looking for stories that take a person, object, event, or phenomenon and somehow, during the course of the plot, “temporally deactivate” it, whatever that may mean in the context of the story. “Temporal deactivation” should refer to something more than a simple death, malfunction, or termination, and instead should touch in some way on issues of time — its flow, distortion, dislocation, etc.
Edited by David B. Coe & Joshua Palmatier, it will contain approximately 14 stories with an average length of up to 6000 words each. It will include short stories by:
C.S. Friedman 
Faith Hunter 
D.B. Jackson
Gini Koch 
Stephen Leigh 
Misty Massey 
Jenna Rhodes 
Edmund R. Schubert
All other slots aside from the named authors will be filled by the open call for submissions following the successful completion of the Kickstarter.
ALTERNATE PEACE:
All too often, alternate histories are based on a battle or assassination. We’re looking for stories where change grew out of more peaceful activities…science, business, and culture. Imagine a world in which the branch point from our own was caused by scientific endeavor, social change, natural forces, or other points of divergence which don’t rely on military activity or violence.
Edited by Steven H Silver & Joshua Palmatier, it will contain approximately 14 stories with an average length of up to 6000 words each. It will include short stories by: 
D.B. Jackson 
Stephen Leigh
Ian R. MacLeod
Kristine Kathryn Rusch
Kari Sperring
Harry Turtledove 
Rick Wilber
All other slots aside from the named authors will be filled by the open call for submissions following the successful completion of the Kickstarter.
The images that will be used to design the cover art are commissioned pieces created by Justin Adams of Varia Studios. The cover art for “Portals” has been completed (see below for the image). The cover art for the other two anthologies will be completed and revealed at a later date. The official covers for the anthology based off this artwork will be revealed sometime after the end of the Kickstarter.
"Portals" by Justin Adams of Varia Studios
If the Kickstarter is funded, the intention is to have all stories handed in by the end of December 2018. We expect the editing and revision process to be finished by the end of February 2019 and the ebook and physical books to be designed, produced, and ready for release by the end of August 2019. Funding will cover the costs of producing the ebook in all standard formats (MOBI, Epub, PDF), producing mass market paperback versions of the anthology for the backers, cover art commission, payment of the editors, advances for the authors (at a minimum of 6 cents per word), and advertising and promotional expenses. Funding above the minimum would be used to increase the advances of the authors, allow for higher production values for the ebooks and books, increase the number of stories in the anthology, and increased advertising.
Stretch goals would include production of promotional bookmarks, an increase in pay for the authors, adding additional story slots to the books, etc. We will be adding more stretch goals as those at the lower levels are achieved. Here are the stretch goals so far:
Stretch Goal: BOOKMARKS! At $27,500, every backer pledged at $20 or more will receive a free promotional bookmark for PORTALS, TEMPORALLY DEACTIVATED, and ALTERNATE PEACE.
Stretch Goal: At $30,000, we will add an additional story to each anthology that is really a THREE-PART STORY cut up into three sections, each section written by the editors of the appropriate anthology (see Update #15 for more details), so each anthology will feature 15 stories minimum AND every backer pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "The Royal Scam" by Gini Koch, the first installment of THE MARTIAN ALLIANCE CHRONICLES series.
Stretch Goal: At $32,500, every backer pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "When Josie Comes Home" by A.E. Stanton (aka Gini Koch), the first installment of THE NEW WEST series.
Stretch Goal: At $35,000, all authors will be paid an additional 1 cent/word AND every backer pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "Three Card Monte" by Gini Koch, the second installment of THE MARTIAN ALLIANCE CHRONICLES series.
Stretch Goal: At $37,500, every backer pleding $7 or more will receive the ebook "Deacon's Ark" by A.E. Stanton (aka Gini Koch), the second installment of THE NEW WEST series.
Stretch Goal: At $40,000, we will add an additional story to each anthology using the submissions from the open call, so each anthology will feature 16 stories minimum AND every backer pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "A Bug's Life" by Gini Koch, the third installment of THE MARTIAN ALLIANCE CHRONICLES series.
Stretch Goal: At $45,000, all authors will be paid an additional 1 cent/word.
Stretch Goal: At $50,000, Zombies Need Brains LLC will produce a FOURTH themed anthology, title to be announced as we approach the stretch goal.

Here’s a brief introduction to the editors of the anthologies:
Patricia Bray: Patricia Bray is the author of a dozen novels, including Devlin’s Luck, which won the 2003 Compton Crook Award for the best first novel in the field of science fiction or fantasy. A multi-genre author whose career spans both epic fantasy and Regency romance, her books have been translated into Russian, German, Portuguese and Hebrew. Patricia lives in a New England college town, where she combines her writing with a full-time career as a Systems Analyst, ensuring that she is never more than a few feet away from a keyboard. Find her online at www.patriciabray.com.
"Devlin's Luck" by Patricia Bray
S.C. Butler: S. C. Butler is a writer living in New Hampshire with his wife and son. He is the author of the "Stoneways" trilogy: Reiffen’s Choice, Queen Ferris, and The Magicians’ Daughter, published by Tor Books; and a contributor of short stories to several anthologies and magazines. Submerged was his debut as an editor.
"Guilds & Glaives" edited by S.C. Butler & Joshua Palmatier
David B. Coe: David B. Coe/D.B. Jackson is the author of twenty novels and as many short stories. As D.B. Jackson (http://www.DBJackson-Author.com), he is the author of TIME’S CHILDREN (October 2018), the first book in The Islevale Cycle, a time travel/epic fantasy series from Angry Robot Books. He also writes the Thieftaker Chronicles, a series set in pre-Revolutionary Boston that combines elements of urban fantasy, mystery, and historical fiction. Under his own name (http://www.DavidBCoe.com) he has written the Crawford Award-winning LonTobyn Chronicle, the critically acclaimed Winds of the Forelands quintet and Blood of the Southlands trilogy, the novelization Ridley Scott’s, ROBIN HOOD, and a contemporary urban fantasy series, the Case Files of Justis Fearsson. He is the co-author of How To Write Magical Words: A Writer’s Companion. He is currently working on several projects, including his next book for Angry Robot and a tie-in project with the History Channel. David has a Ph.D. in U.S. history from Stanford University. His books have been translated into a dozen languages.
"Time's Children" by D.B. Jackson
Joshua Palmatier: A professor of mathematics at SUNY Oneonta, Joshua Palmatier has published nine novels—the “Throne of Amenkor” series (The Skewed Throne, The Cracked Throne, The Vacant Throne) with DAW, the “Well of Sorrows” series (Well of Sorrows, Leaves of Flame, Breath of Heaven) with Baen and Zombies Need Brains, and the "Ley" series (Shattering the Ley, Threading the Needle, Reaping the Aurora) with DAW. He is currently at work on the start of a new series. He has also published numerous short stories—“Mastihooba” in Close Encounters of the Urban Kind and “Tears of Blood” in Beauty Has Her Way (both edited by Jennifer Brozek), “The River” in River (edited by Alma Alexander), and "Daughter of the Sands" in Apollo's Daughters (edited by Brian Young). Find out more at www.joshuapalmatier.com and www.zombiesneedbrains.com.
The "Ley" series by Joshua Palmatier
Steven H Silver: Steven H Silver is a sixteen-time Hugo Award nominee and was the publisher of the Hugo-nominated fanzine Argentus as well as the editor and publisher of ISFiC Press for 8 years. He has also edited books for DAW and NESFA Press. He began publishing short fiction in 2008 and his most recently published story is "Doing Business at Hodputt’s Emporium" in Galaxy’s Edge. In 1995, he created the Sidewise Award for Alternate History and has served as the award’s administrator ever since. Steven has chaired the first Midwest Construction, Windycon three times, and the SFWA Nebula Conference 5 times as well as serving as the Event Coordinator for SFWA. He was programming chair for Chicon 2000 and Vice Chair of Chicon 7. Previously, Silver received a Master’s in Medieval History.
"Magical Beginnings" edited by Steven H Silver & Martin H. Greenberg
Zombies Need Brains LLC is a small press owned and operated by Joshua Palmatier that focuses on producing professional quality science fiction and fantasy themed anthologies initially funded by Kickstarters. Having successfully published ten anthologies in the last five years, ZNB is currently expanding its anthology production, with the intent to eventually publish stand-alone books once the press has gained its footing. Check out the webpage at www.zombiesneedbrains.comand the online store at https://squareup.com/market/zombies-need-brains-llc. Signup for our newsletter at http://eepurl.com/dv3TLv. You can also find Zombies Need Brains on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/zombiesneedbrainsllc/) and Twitter (@ZNBLLC).

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any production of a book, the timeline for delivery of the book may change due to unexpected delays in the editing process or the production process (such as a delay in printing at the press, etc). Every effort will be made to have the books ready for release and in backers’ hands by August 2019. Also, there is always a slight chance that life and circumstances will force a confirmed anchor author to drop out of the anthology. In the unlikely event that an author cannot deliver a story for whatever reason, their slot would be filled with an author from the slush pile. Since everyone involved—both anchor authors and editors—are professionals in the field already, there is no real expectation that there will be a delay or that the confirmed authors will not deliver, but it does happen on occasion.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
The latest Zombies Need Brains Kickstarter is NOW LIVE! Click through the link below and help us fund THREE new SF&F anthologies about deities, derelicts, and clashing cultures! Awesome authors, tons of special rewards (most limited), and an open call for submissions to fill out the anthologies once we're funded. Back us if you can! The anthologies are:  
THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY: Tales of the gods fitting into our modern day society!

AND WE MADE IT!  WOOHOO!!!  THANK YOU, BACKERS!!!  THANK YOU, ANCHOR AUTHORS!!!  THANK YOU, EVERYONE WHO SHARED AND SIGNAL BOOSTED!!!
The Zombies Need Brains Kickstarter has reached its goal! Time to drin--I mean, time to reach for those stretch goals!  We've got 24 hours to try to hit $30K, which will introduce a FOURTH anthology (ebook only) called RAMMING THE RAMPARTS.  This anthology asks authors to explore these and other absurd, surrealistic alternate histories.  The inspiration comes from our current President's recent commentary on the Fourth of July, including the idea that our Army "took over the airports" during the Revolutionary War.  What if there had been airports during that war?  Absurd!  George Washington was not a fighter pilot!  There was no "Battle at LaGuardia Baggage Claim"!  And yet...  The anthology will contain 12 stories by Gerald Brandt, David B. Coe, Esther Friesner, Elektra Hammond, Nancy Holzner, Walter H. Hunt, Gini Koch, Kristine Kathryn Rusch, Rhondi Salsitz, Steven H Silver, Alan Smale, and Harry Turtledove.  It will be edited by Joshua Palmatier.

And we've got some GREAT anchor authors!  So pitch in and support small presses!

campaign.story:
For almost a decade and a half now, I've been writing stories about the Cliff's End Castle Guard, starting in 2004 with Dragon Precinct, and continuing in four more novels and fifteen short stories, with two more novels and a bunch more short stories still to come. (And for those of you who Kickstarted Mermaid Precinct, that is still in progress, and should be done in the next few weeks, with the book itself ready some time after that. You'll be seeing more in-progress chapters this week.)
One of those stories I did via Kickstarter, entitled "Gan Brightblade vs. Mitos the Mighty." The response to that story -- which didn't actually include any members of the Cliff's End Castle Guard -- was strong enough that I've wanted to write some more stories that look at the greater world of Flingaria beyond Cliff's End and the cops who maintain law and order therein.
To that end, I've written a story called "The Fall of Iaron." It tells a story of the history of Flingaria, in particular a battle that took place in Iaron, one of the other human city-states that's is allied with Cliff's End under the rule of King Marcus and Queen Marta. 
"The Fall of Iaron" is about history, about storytelling, about political machinations, and about what makes a hero and what makes a tyrant and what makes a villain. I'm quite pleased with it, and I hope you'll enjoy it, too.
The story is already written, and the only changes still to be made to it are the names of up to ten of characters in the story who will be renamed based on who pledges at the $65 level. Aside from that -- and adding the acknowledgments to include all you kind folks who pledge -- the story is done and edited, so as soon as the project is funded, I can start sending out the main reward, to wit, the story itself. The eBooks should also go out in relatively short order as well.
If you just want the story itself, it's only two bucks, but there are other nifty rewards at higher levels, including swag, me reading the story, other books of mine, and a new one, offering my editorial services! I've been a professional editor for almost thirty years now, and I'm offering editing of either your short fiction (20,000 words or less) or your novel (100,000 words or less) at a lower rate than my usual.
So please, fund this project, and get a nifty new story in this fun universe I've created.

The story's already written, so the risks are minimal. I just hope there's enough interest in the broader spectrum of the world of the "Precinct" books.

A Fantasy Role Playing Renaissance.
At this rich time in gaming, tabletop roleplaying gamers have never had it so good - every group of gamers can find the game that suits their own tastes. The best of games capture the tried elements of 40 years of fantasy roleplaying evolution: balance, flow of play, a smooth learning curve, and system that well-serves setting.
In 2007, Metal, Magic and Lore was introduced, with its powerful system with emphasis on realism and grit with speed of play. MML developed a loyal, passionate following that has stayed with it ever since. And NOW based both on the desires of those players and critics of the game, we are proud to integrate a number of upgraded improvements, and introduce the  Metal, Magic, and Lore Revised Edition.
Are You One Of Us?
Following the traditions of Tolkien, Howard, Brooks, and Abercrombie, in Metal, Magic and Lore nearly any literary character can be brought to life due to its class-less, level-less character system. Here you’ll find Men, Dwarves, Elves, and others locked in struggle against adversaries common and fantastic. MML is for a particular kind of fantasy gamer: a lover of fantasy, but also a lover of the rich experience of simulation and realism; mature role-playing at its best.
New to the game? Eight reasons to try it -
This is traditional fantasy, a time of Men, Dwarves and Elves. There are 3 other offshoot races, which do not deviate far from these classic archetypes which shaped the very origins of the genre! 
Characters are created by allocating Attribute points to nine attributes. Secondary attributes are calculated from these, so all of them are important; Min/Maxing has been proven to be nearly impossible within the MML architecture. Characters are class-less and level-less, and are created by selecting skills as negotiated by the player and GM to form the character composite. The revised addition adds clarity and definition to this to make it easier to start, as well as some pre-assembled templates. Characters get better by improving skills, making them more effective at interaction, better at attacking and defending, and casting spells.  
Skill checks are a percentile-system based. Roll dice under the percentage for success. All task attempts in the game are given by the same universal formula: combat, magic and social interaction are all resolved as a combination of skill and the difficulty of the task attempted. GMs add/subtract modifiers as per situation. Characters skills are developed only by them being used, and all types of skills are needed for survival!
Economics in the game are dramatic as seen with character Social Class - the Commoner, the Merchant Class and the Lesser Noble, akin to the castes of Medieval Europe at about the 12th century, so coin and provisions are key to adventure. Travel is part of the adventure, as is the countryside and rumors that it contains.
Combat is deadly. Initiative matters because striking first can mean not being attacked. Character A attacks, character B defends, then a position is chosen on the body, over which there may or may not be armor. And well, with a sword against no armor - you can imagine what happens. Hit Points are location based and never increase (only by a point or two in the advanced rules).  Characters become no tougher in the game, just harder to hit while they hit others better.
Magic has lower power than many other fantasy games, but is as effective due to the game setting. Regardless of the type of magic, a point pool system is used to determine amounts of spells. The method of casting uses the same percentile system as is described above. Players do find this approach refreshing, though in the revised edition we will be correcting some scaling errors and rounding out the magic so that it better reflects the lore of the game as is intended.
Beasts are creatures foul and feisty, but there are not many. We look to publish about 50. Beasts are tied to the ecology, which will be portrayed in future regional atlases. Most current fans and gamers have not gotten through using even 20 in a multi-session campaign. Orcs, Ogres, Goblins, Giants, and many traditional archetypes is what you will see here.
If you like mature storytelling, literary fantasy which can easily mimic any HBO episode of Game of Thrones, the idea that it only takes 7 or 8 orcs to present an experienced set of characters with a problem, then you will probably want to try Metal, Magic and Lore.
Pledge Levels
Each Pledge Level includes all rewards of any of lower dollar value, so your collection will accumulate with your pledge! And to make things easier on everyone, we are sharing all shipping costs with you!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
After 12 years, we are very interested an accomplishing something NEW - to meet the demands of our loyal customers as well as understand the criticisms of those who we hope will become our customers. As such, we will not do anything short of bringing the game quality to an entirely new level, by paying for great professionals, for exhaustive testing, and having a commitment to easier play experience and visual beauty. And so, this budget is inclusive of all that.

No volunteering, no sub-standard help, no favors. Just professionals performing professional work, on a product that has gained wisdom from being in the market for a decade. With that, comes expense. And so - the goals you see.

While we have other products in further development, MML is taking the foreground of effort with your support. No other game supplement in the 5th Epoch portfolio is as important. And without the customer pledge, it is more than challenging to achieve in today's market. And so, we leave ourselves to your bidding!

Thanks again for all the loyalists who have believed in us over the years -

updates.update_userinfo: For the Newly Interested - Metal Magic and Lore Basics
updates.update_content:
This post is for anyone who has heard of Metal, Magic and Lore or is interested, but not been exposed to game play or setting. Here is an overview:
Setting
This is traditional fantasy, with Elves, Dwarves and Men. There are 3 other offshoot races, one variety of Elves (Gray and Tribal), and Gnomes, which in MML are a faction of Dwarves which broke off from the traditions of their brethren, in service of survival of the race. There are also the smaller Hilfolk, who because of their disinterest in history, have not traced back their original origins.

updates.update_userinfo: For Loyal Fans - What will be different? Details, details, details
updates.update_content:
To be clear, this post is specifically written for those players that have come to love the architecture of MML, and the setting and lore it stands for. If you are new to MML, this may or may not hold as much meaning for you, but you are free to read it through anyway, of course.
#1. Two Books instead of One
The MML Revised Player's Rulebook will have more useful information for players - period. Some material will be reduced as it belongs in the accompanying GM's Companion Book. The added materials will all be in service of making the game simpler and easier to start. The GM's Companion will replace a large part of the GM PDF material out there, and have a host of other useful information not yet published.

Publishing is a tough business, no matter which side of the table you are on. Even authors with a big following can find themselves with a manuscript that the big houses just aren't buying.
A hard fact, but one that works in our favor as we at eSpec get to work with some pretty amazing authors, ones that regularly appear on the list of Nebula finalists and on bestsellers lists.
These books are by two amazing authors, Bud Sparhawk and Christoher L. Bennett, both literary powerhouses bringing you great sci fi stories.
Shattered Dreams by Bud Sparhawk
What Happens When Very Little Survives First Contact?  

Settling on a colony planet is hard, building a life and conquering a new frontier far from the cradle of humanity, where contact is infrequent and supply drops even more so. Colonists must depend on their grit and ingenuity.  
When a garbled message is received by unconventional means, warning of an alien attack, many on Morrow think it a joke, or spotty communication. No one can believe what they are hearing.  
There is no time to reconsider as flashes light up across the planet’s horizon. Not even knowing they aren’t alone in the universe, humanity falls victim to first contact and very few on Morrow are left alive, somehow overlooked by an alien force bent on their destruction. As they struggle to survive and avoid notice they are oblivious to the deadly war being waged on a universal scale.
Humanity shows its will to survive the Shardies War.
(Cover design by Mike McPhail, McP Digital Graphics.)
Among the Wild Cybers by Christopher L. Bennett
Tales Beyond the Superhuman   
When the line between life and technology blurs, humanity must adjust its understanding of the universe. From bestselling author Christopher L. Bennett comes Among the Wild Cybers, eight tales portraying a future of challenge and conflict, but also of hope born from the courage and idealism of those heroes willing to stand up for what is right.  
An intrepid naturalist risks her future to save a new form of life that few consider worth saving.  
An apprentice superhero must stand alone against an insane superintelligence to earn her name.  
A cybernetic slave fights to save her kind from a liberation not of their choosing.  
A seasoned diplomat and mother must out-negotiate fearsome alien traders to save a colony’s children.  
A homicide detective serves in a world where curing death has only made murder more baffling.  
These and other heroes strive to make their corners of the universe better—no matter how much the odds are stacked against them. Includes the brand-new tale, Aspiring to Be Angels, prequel to the novel Only Superhuman.

Bud Sparhawk has been a three-time novella finalist for the Nebula award: Primrose and Thorn (Analog, May 1996), Magic’s Price (Analog, March 2001), and Clay’s Pride (Analog, July/August 2004). His work has appeared in two Year’s Best anthologies: Year’s Best SF #11 (EOS), David Harwell-Editor) and The Years Best Science Fiction, Fourteenth Annual Collection, (St Martins Press, Garner Dozois – Editor.)  
His novel Distant Seas (Fantastic Books) is available from Amazon and other booksellers as trade paperback and eBook. He has a mass market paperback novel: Vixen (Cosmos) and two print collections: Sam Boone: Front To Back (Foxacre Press, 2001) and Dancing with Dragons (Wildside Press, 2008). He has three e-Novels available through Amazon and other channels.
Bud’s short stories have appeared frequently in Analog Fact/Fiction, less so in Asimov’s, as well as in five Defending the Future and other anthologies, publications and audio books. He has put out several collections of some of his published works in ebook format. 
 A complete bibliography can be found at: http://budsparhawk.com. He also writes an occasional blog on the pain of writing at http://budsparhawk.blogspot.com.
Christopher L. Bennett is a lifelong resident of Cincinnati, Ohio, with a B.S. in Physics and a B.A. in History from the University of Cincinnati. A fan of science and science fiction since age five, he has spent the past two decades selling original short fiction to magazines such as Analog Science Fiction and Fact and BuzzyMag. For the past dozen years, he has been one of Pocket Books' most prolific and popular authors of Star Trek tie-in fiction, including the epic Next Generation prequel The Buried Age, the Star Trek: Department of Temporal Investigations series, and the ongoing Star Trek: Enterprise—Rise of the Federation series. His original novel Only Superhuman, perhaps the first hard science fiction superhero novel, was voted Library Journal's SF/Fantasy Debut of the Month for October 2012. His short story collection Hub Space: Tales from the Greater Galaxy is available in e-book and print formats from Mystique Press.  Christopher's homepage, fiction annotations, and blog can be found at christopherlbennett.wordpress.com, and his Facebook author page is at www.facebook.com/ChristopherLBennettAuthor.
Author and graphic artist Mike McPhail is a member of the Military Writers Society of America. He is dedicated to helping his fellow service members (and those deserving civilians) in their efforts to become authors/editors/artists, as well as supporting related organizations in their efforts to help those “who have given their all for us.” www.milscifi.com He is best known as the editor and illustrator of the award-winning Defending The Future series of military science fiction anthologies, which just celebrated it’s tenth anniversary. www.defendingthefuture.com In 2015 he added the title of publisher, as the co-owner of eSpec Books LLC, Speculative Fiction Publishing. www.especbooks.com

updates.update_content:
Hello, everyone.
I hope you are enjoying your new year. Just a line to let you know I have 42 hours left my personal campaign for my three collections, More Tips from the Handyman (a writer's guide) and two short story collections. If you have a chance, could you check it out, maybe spread the word? I have run out of steam and this poor baby has been languishing. Make 100: Three Collected Works.

Good morning! (apologies to anyone receiving this multiple times. KS hasn't given me a way to update you all at once yet.)
Just 27 hours left in our current campaign for, originally, two science fiction novels by David Sherman (co-writing with Keith DeCandido) and Christopher Bennett. So far we have unlocked ELEVEN stretch goals for six bonus short stories, a cool custom patch, and FOUR more books!!!

Hi, everyone.
We hope you are doing well during this trying time.
Despite the corona-chaos going on, we are still striving to be productive and continue to provide quality speculative fiction. We have just launched a campaign to fund two science fiction books and hope you might check it out.

Hi, all.    
I am managing campaign for another creator, Jeff Sturgeon's Last Cities of Earth. I thought some of you might be interested. It ends in just under an hour.   Last Cities of Earth is a universe depicting humanity's survival in the face of global catastrophe. Born from the mind’s eye of, award-winning artist, Jeff Sturgeon. Last Cities of Earth is a stunning collection of tales and imagery. For years, Jeff envisioned entire cities floating above the clouds. At first, a single metropolis emerged. Then, over time, more and more massive structures seemingly rose into the sky.

Just 72 hours left in the current campaign. We have unlocked two anthologies and are a hair's breadth away from unlocking a single-author collection by Robert E. Waters.
There are loads of bonuses and stretch goals that have been unlocked.

We have just two weeks left on the current campaign. We are funded and have unlocked three stretch goals. Now all backers pledging $5 or more receive three extra short stories by myself, James Daniel Ross, and Mike McPhail, in addition to any bonuses and pledge rewards. We have a lot more lined up, but first...

Hi All,
It has been a while, but we are preparing to launch our next campaign, DEFENDING THE FUTURE: IN HARM'S WAY.

Yay!!!!
Absolutely all rewards have been distributed or shipped. Most of you should start to receive the physical books by the end of the week or early next week. Sorry...for my international folks it's going to take a little longer :)
Now that that is all done... For those of you who chose Among the Wild Cybers for your reward and are kicking yourselves for not pledging for Shattered Dreams as well, now that you are out of reading material...I have great news for you!

campaign.story:
We originally formed out of a simple idea to make money. Since our conception the organisation and our point of view has drastically changed! Our environment is in turmoil. Bees are dying at an alarming rate, and we want to see the balance restored. We are a tiny company that places live and active hives in residential and commercial properties to boost bee numbers across Wales, to ensure pollination, ensuring a greener environment and educate the public about bees and the unsung little hero that keeps us all fed!  
The money raised here, will buy new hives and equipment and allow us to spread the word further afield about bees and promote the work that bees do within our daily environment! Bees seem to have the reputation and a stinging unpleasant pest, but that is not the case! Bees only sting as a last resort and die after stinging! If we lost the bees tomorrow, one third of all the food in the world would die, there just isn't enough other pollinators to take care of it all! Why not protect the environment and help our little bees out from the comfort of where you are, simply place a pledge, support our work by visiting us on Facebook, or apply for a hive to have at home.
Thank you!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We live in a society of convenience and instant gratification, we do not want to take that from you, but how glad would you be to do one little action to improve our environment and make our planet that little bit greener, one hive at a time?

There are many things that we suffer from, pesticides, deforestation, hedgerow removal, wild habitat being destroyed, natural disease and pests and yes even humans with fly killer and bug sprays.

By funding a hive you help us grow, we save the bees, the planet gets greener, what other project offers that warm fuzzy glowing sensation your feeling right now!

One of our authors will collaborate with you to create a short story based on your suggestions (with some restrictions - dependent on author) and you get to name the main character. The story will be shared with everyone who pledges Investigator or above in a DRM free eformat, with proper accolades to you for your special role as Muse. You will receive a specially bound and signed copy. This tier's special reward will not be ready by the publication date of the anthology. The extra reward will take a few months to produce, but it will be worth waiting for. If multiple instances of this reward are selected, the stories will be collected and bound together for each of the Patrons.

updates.update_content: Okay, tooting my own horn a bit here, but thought this group might be interested in the following press release:

Yep, it's been a while since my Familiar Spirits Kickstarter finished up and all backers got their items. So, why am I showing up in your feed now? Sure, I'd still love to get more reviews for Familiar Spirits, and for Frame Shop, which I Kickstarted before that (heck, for all of my books and stories), but that's not the purpose of this update. The reason I'm contacting you at the moment is because I want to bring somebody else's Kickstarter to your attention.
You see, my company used to own a time travel roleplaying game and I wrote a number of adventures for it. I've also written a number of time travel tales in my time, so I couldn't help but be intrigued when I ran across Singular Irregularity, a Kickstarter for an anthology about time travel gone terribly wrong. Better yet, I knew some of the authors from other projects. But, best of all, when I contacted Kimber Grey, she gave me a chance to join the project, adding my story "Standing Still" to the temporal mix. And ... since I used to run those time travel adventures I wrote for the Timemaster Roleplaying Game at conventions, she added a pledge level whereby I will run one of my old time travel adventures for the backer of that reward and five of their friends. You can check it all out at:

updates.update_content: It's been six months since the Familiar Spirits anthology of ghost stories came out. I hope you enjoyed this publication and just maybe found it a bit frightening. But, here's the really scary part. Although the reactions from readers and the reviews posted have been good, only a very few reviews have been posted on Amazon, bn.com, Goodreads, Shelfari, and private blogs. If you're a horror anthology fan, please encourage more horror anthologies by telling people about them. And, if you're someone who backed the Kickstarter to support a favorite author or friend, help them out by posting a review of their story or the whole anthology. It only takes a few minutes, but it can help them (and me) enormously.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Sometimes even the most professional of publications hit a snag, and the more people involved, the higher the potential for timeline adjustments.

Pendragon Press is dedicated to providing the highest quality stories, visuals, and audio for the Elysian Springs Anthology, and in the event this level of quality requires a timeline adjustment, backers will be notified of the setback, the action plan, and the new projected date of fulfillment.

We've received over 30 pitches for fantastic stories, but we won't be able to include all of them in the anthology. The good news is, there will be plenty of quality stories to substitute In the event that an author drops or is unable to complete the required revisions.

updates.update_content:
I would like to thank you all for your willingness to contribute to Elysian Springs: Adventures from the Nursing Home for Aging Superheroes. After much consideration over the past week, I've decided to cancel this particular run at funding for several reasons, not the least of which is wanting to have another go at it when I have more time, perspective, and capital to give the anthology the push it needs.
Other reasons include an unfortunate interpretation of the anthology's tone that, I suspect, drove away many would-be contributors. The purpose of the anthology was to empower (literally) seniors through fiction, humanizing an often-sidelined population by showing them through the lens of the superhero mythos. The pitches and stories I have received reflect this sensitive and empowering vision of the anthology.
